caption_text: In Fig. 5, we see the effect of the superficial gas velocity on the product gas composition, particularly the ratio of hydrogen to carbon monoxide. Since the feed gas composition is held constant at forty percent inlet oxygen, the effect of an increase in carbon monoxide production with superficial gas velocity is clearly the result of an increase in the bed temperature, shown to occur in Fig. 4. It is well known that lower temperatures favor the production of carbon dioxide, not only because it is the primary product of carbon combustion [27,281 but also because the resulting carbon dioxide reduction to monoxide is extremely slow at lower temperatures.
raw_window: In Fig. 5, we see the effect of the superficial gas velocity on the product gas composition, particularly the ratio of hydrogen to carbon monoxide.

Since the feed gas composition is held constant at forty percent inlet oxygen, the effect of an increase in carbon monoxide production with superficial gas velocity is clearly the result of an increase in the bed temperature, shown to occur in Fig. 4.

It is well known that lower temperatures favor the production of carbon dioxide, not only because it is the primary product of carbon combustion [27,281 but also because the resulting carbon dioxide reduction to monoxide is extremely slow at lower temperatures.

caption_text: In considering the effect of homogeneous kinetics in the jets and bubbles, we can observe, from Fig. 3, that for equal sets of independent parameters the carbon conversion obtained is less for the model which con- siders reaction in the dilute phase than for the model without. It is apparent that as highly exothermic hydrogen and carbon monoxide combustion occur there is less free oxygen available to react exothermically at the coal surface. The steam and carbon dioxide resulting from the homogeneous reactions diffuse simultaneously with the heat generated by the reactions to the emulsion phase where the steam and carbon dioxide react endo- thermically with carbon.
raw_window: In considering the effect of homogeneous kinetics in the jets and bubbles, we can observe, from Fig. 3, that for equal sets of independent parameters the carbon conversion obtained is less for the model which con- siders reaction in the dilute phase than for the model without.
It is apparent that as highly exothermic hydrogen and carbon monoxide combustion occur there is less free oxygen available to react exothermically at the coal surface.

The steam and carbon dioxide resulting from the homogeneous reactions diffuse simultaneously with the heat generated by the reactions to the emulsion phase where the steam and carbon dioxide react endo- thermically with carbon.

caption_text: From the curves of Fig. 4 we can see that, for the most part, the overall bed temperature is greater when dilute phase reaction is considered, this of course resulting from the homogeneous hydrogen and carbon monoxide combustion reactions. From the graph of the L-niodel it is apparent that as the feed gas flow rate increases the increase in available oxygen spurs the exothermic homogeneous combustion reactions to the extent that the overall bed temperature rises sharply. It is expected that as more oxygen is introduced into the system the yield of carbon oxides will increase.
raw_window: From the curves of Fig. 4 we can see that, for the most part, the overall bed temperature is greater when dilute phase reaction is considered, this of course resulting from the homogeneous hydrogen and carbon monoxide combustion reactions.

From the graph of the L-niodel it is apparent that as the feed gas flow rate increases the increase in available oxygen spurs the exothermic homogeneous combustion reactions to the extent that the overall bed temperature rises sharply.
It is expected that as more oxygen is introduced into the system the yield of carbon oxides will increase.

caption_text: From Fig. 5 we can see readily that for all feed gas flow rates the relative amount of hydrogen to carbon monox- ide is less when dilute phase reactions are considered in the bed. This effect can be attributed to additional com- bustion via the homogeneous oxidation reactions which reduce available hydrogen and increase the yield of carbon oxides. Influence of the inflowing gar composition Reactant gas composition can have a radical effect on reactor performance and is the primary means of con- trolling bed temperature in most gasification processes.
raw_window: From Fig. 5 we can see readily that for all feed gas flow rates the relative amount of hydrogen to carbon monox- ide is less when dilute phase reactions are considered in the bed.
This effect can be attributed to additional com- bustion via the homogeneous oxidation reactions which reduce available hydrogen and increase the yield of carbon oxides.

Influence of the inflowing gar composition Reactant gas composition can have a radical effect on reactor performance and is the primary means of con- trolling bed temperature in most gasification processes.

caption_text: From Fig. 6 we can see that, at a given fluidization velocity, carbon conversion increases with oxygen input. This trend is similar to that previously shown for an increase in superficial gas velocity (Fig. 3) with carbon conversion increasing linearly with available oxygen to a point at which the rate of conversion then tends to increase at a slower rate. Total conversion is not obtain- able because of carbon loss with the ash by mechanical removal and elutriation from the bed.
raw_window: From Fig. 6 we can see that, at a given fluidization velocity, carbon conversion increases with oxygen input.

This trend is similar to that previously shown for an increase in superficial gas velocity (Fig. 3) with carbon conversion increasing linearly with available oxygen to a point at which the rate of conversion then tends to increase at a slower rate.
Total conversion is not obtain- able because of carbon loss with the ash by mechanical removal and elutriation from the bed.

caption_text: In considering steady state average bed temperature, it is apparent from Fig. 7 that operating temperature increases with available oxygen. The rapid exothermic combustion reactions generate a substantial amount of heal We can see from Fig. R that product carbon monoxide increases as the quantity of available oxygen increases. For the con- ditions specified, one can see that more carbon monoxide than hydrogen results when the inlet oxygen concen- tration exceeds approximately 25 30%.

caption_text: Furthermore, we note from Fig. 8 that the L-model, for all feed gas compositions considered, predicts a higher yield of carbon monoxide than hydrogen. As previously noted, this is due to the oxidation of hydrogen by homogeneous combustion reactions in the jets and bubbles. Of course the yield of carbon monoxide increases with the in- creased availability of oxygen.
raw_window: Furthermore, we note from Fig. 8 that the L-model, for all feed gas compositions considered, predicts a higher yield of carbon monoxide than hydrogen.
As previously noted, this is due to the oxidation of hydrogen by homogeneous combustion reactions in the jets and bubbles.
Of course the yield of carbon monoxide increases with the in- creased availability of oxygen.

caption_text: The model without dilute phase reaction shows an increase in bed temperature with transfer while, in that model which accounts for reaction in the jets and bubbles, bed temperature decreases as crossflow is in- creased (Fig. 10). Apparently when dilute reactions are not considered the increased interchange results in oxygen being transferred more rapidly to the emulsion phase where exothermic heterogeneous combustion occurs and the heat generated is subsequently transfer- red throughout the bed. On the other hand, for the model with dilute phase reactions, hydrogen and carbon monoxide diffuse from the emulsion phase to the jets and bubbtes where they react with oxygen to yield carbon dioxide and water vapor.
raw_window: The model without dilute phase reaction shows an increase in bed temperature with transfer while, in that model which accounts for reaction in the jets and bubbles, bed temperature decreases as crossflow is in- creased (Fig. 10).

Apparently when dilute reactions are not considered the increased interchange results in oxygen being transferred more rapidly to the emulsion phase where exothermic heterogeneous combustion occurs and the heat generated is subsequently transfer- red throughout the bed.

On the other hand, for the model with dilute phase reactions, hydrogen and carbon monoxide diffuse from the emulsion phase to the jets and bubbtes where they react with oxygen to yield carbon dioxide and water vapor.

caption_text: From the relations set forth above and those contained in Table I it is apparent that one can compute the volume fraction of all phases, their volumes, and the total reactor volume as well as the absolute Velocities of the two gas phases throughout the bed.

Solids population balance It is apparent that for a combined oxygen steam reactant feed the true representation of the system is a combination of both shrinking particles and particles of varying density.
The actual particle behavior depends on the properties of the coal being processed and on operating parameters such as gas flow rate and bed temperature and pressure.

caption_text: Mass and heat cmssflow between phases Mass and heat transfer between the bubbles and the interstitial gas and between the interstitial gas and the particles can be reasonably well described by the rela- tions of Kunii and Levenspiel[17] and Ranz and Marshall [181, respectively, as given in Table 1.
raw_window: Mass and heat cmssflow between phases Mass and heat transfer between the bubbles and the interstitial gas and between the interstitial gas and the particles can be reasonably well described by the rela- tions of Kunii and Levenspiel[17] and Ranz and Marshall [181, respectively, as given in Table 1.
In considering the jetting interstitial gas interchange it is well known that the jetting region plays a critical role in determining reactor performance, particularly in large beds.
Cooke et al.

caption_text: From the literature we have compiled the kinetic data shown in Table 2.
raw_window: From the literature we have compiled the kinetic data shown in Table 2.

By accounting for the kinetics of the water gas shift and carbon monoxide and hydrogen combustion reactions this model accounts naturally for the depletion of inlet oxygen and hence a combustion zone close to the inlet gas distributor.

This approach differs significantly from recent modeling studies [3 4] in which n combustion zone of negligible volume (where the carbon oxidation reaction alone is assumed to com- pletely consume all carbon within this zone) has been superimposed on the models.
